function.description: Invoke the default activate mode function of a ghost pad.

parameter.name: active
parameter.parameter_description: whether the pad should be active or not.

function.return: %TRUE if the operation was successful.

function.name: gst_ghost_pad_construct
function.description:
Finish initialization of a newly allocated ghost pad.
This function is most useful in language bindings and when subclassing #GstGhostPad; plugin and application developers normally will not call this function. Call this function directly after a call to g_object_new (GST_TYPE_GHOST_PAD, "direction", @dir, ..., NULL).
function.return: %TRUE if the construction succeeds, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gst_ghost_pad_get_target
function.description: Get the target pad of @gpad. Unref target pad after usage.
function.return: the target #GstPad, can be %NULL if the ghostpad has no target set. Unref target pad after usage.

function.name: gst_ghost_pad_internal_activate_mode_default
function.description: Invoke the default activate mode function of a proxy pad that is owned by a ghost pad.

parameter.name: active
parameter.parameter_description: whether the pad should be active or not.

function.return: %TRUE if the operation was successful.

function.name: gst_ghost_pad_new
function.description:
Create a new ghostpad with @target as the target. The direction will be taken from the target pad. @target must be unlinked.
Will ref the target.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the new pad, or %NULL to assign a default name

function.return: a new #GstPad, or %NULL in case of an error.

function.name: gst_ghost_pad_new_from_template
function.description:
Create a new ghostpad with @target as the target. The direction will be taken from the target pad. The template used on the ghostpad will be @template.
Will ref the target.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the new pad, or %NULL to assign a default name.

parameter.name: templ
parameter.parameter_description: the #GstPadTemplate to use on the ghostpad.

function.return: a new #GstPad, or %NULL in case of an error.

function.name: gst_ghost_pad_new_no_target
function.description:
Create a new ghostpad without a target with the given direction. A target can be set on the ghostpad later with the gst_ghost_pad_set_target() function.
The created ghostpad will not have a padtemplate.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the new pad, or %NULL to assign a default name.

function.return: a new #GstPad, or %NULL in case of an error.

function.name: gst_ghost_pad_new_no_target_from_template
function.description: Create a new ghostpad based on @templ, without setting a target. The direction will be taken from the @templ.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the new pad, or %NULL to assign a default name

parameter.name: templ
parameter.parameter_description: the #GstPadTemplate to create the ghostpad from.

function.return: a new #GstPad, or %NULL in case of an error.

function.name: gst_ghost_pad_set_target
function.description: Set the new target of the ghostpad @gpad. Any existing target is unlinked and links to the new target are established. if @newtarget is %NULL the target will be cleared.
function.return: %TRUE if the new target could be set. This function can return %FALSE when the internal pads could not be linked.

function.name: gst_guint64_to_gdouble
function.description: Convert @value to a gdouble.
function.return: @value converted to a #gdouble.

function.name: gst_harness_add_element_full
function.description:
Adds a #GstElement to an empty #GstHarness
MT safe.

parameter.name: element
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstElement to add to the harness (transfer none)

parameter.name: hsrc
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstStaticPadTemplate describing the harness srcpad. %NULL will not create a harness srcpad.

parameter.name: element_sinkpad_name
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the name of the element sinkpad that is then linked to the harness srcpad. Can be a static or request or a sometimes pad that has been added. %NULL will not get/request a sinkpad from the element. (Like if the element is a src.)

parameter.name: hsink
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstStaticPadTemplate describing the harness sinkpad. %NULL will not create a harness sinkpad.

parameter.name: element_srcpad_name

function.name: gst_harness_add_element_sink_pad
function.description:
Links the specifed #GstPad the @GstHarness srcpad.
MT safe.

parameter.name: sinkpad
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstPad to link to the harness srcpad

function.name: gst_harness_add_element_src_pad
function.description:
Links the specifed #GstPad the @GstHarness sinkpad. This can be useful if perhaps the srcpad did not exist at the time of creating the harness, like a demuxer that provides a sometimes-pad after receiving data.
MT safe.

parameter.name: srcpad
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstPad to link to the harness sinkpad

function.name: gst_harness_add_parse
function.description:
Parses the @launchline and puts that in a #GstBin, and then attches the supplied #GstHarness to the bin.
MT safe.

parameter.name: launchline
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar describing a gst-launch type line

function.name: gst_harness_add_probe
function.description:
A convenience function to allows you to call gst_pad_add_probe on a #GstPad of a #GstElement that are residing inside the #GstHarness, by using normal gst_pad_add_probe syntax
MT safe.

parameter.name: pad_name
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the name of the pad to attach the probe to

function.name: gst_harness_add_sink
function.description:
Similar to gst_harness_add_sink_harness, this is a convenience to directly create a sink-harness using the @sink_element_name name specified.
MT safe.

parameter.name: sink_element_name
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the name of a #GstElement

function.name: gst_harness_add_sink_harness
function.description:
Similar to gst_harness_add_src, this allows you to send the data coming out of your harnessed #GstElement to a sink-element, allowing to test different responses the element output might create in sink elements. An example might be an existing sink providing some analytical data on the input it receives that can be useful to your testing. If the goal is to test a sink-element itself, this is better acheived using gst_harness_new directly on the sink.
If a sink-harness already exists it will be replaced.
MT safe.

parameter.name: sink_harness
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstHarness to be added as a sink-harness.

function.name: gst_harness_add_sink_parse
function.description:
Similar to gst_harness_add_sink, this allows you to specify a launch-line instead of just an element name. See gst_harness_add_src_parse for details.
MT safe.

parameter.name: launchline
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the name of a #GstElement

function.name: gst_harness_add_src
function.description:
Similar to gst_harness_add_src_harness, this is a convenience to directly create a src-harness using the @src_element_name name specified.
MT safe.

parameter.name: src_element_name
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the name of a #GstElement

parameter.name: has_clock_wait
parameter.parameter_description: a #gboolean specifying if the #GstElement uses gst_clock_wait_id internally.

function.name: gst_harness_add_src_harness
function.description:
A src-harness is a great way of providing the #GstHarness with data. By adding a src-type #GstElement, it is then easy to use functions like gst_harness_push_from_src or gst_harness_src_crank_and_push_many to provide your harnessed element with input. The @has_clock_wait variable is a greate way to control you src-element with, in that you can have it produce a buffer for you by simply cranking the clock, and not have it spin out of control producing buffers as fast as possible.
If a src-harness already exists it will be replaced.
MT safe.

parameter.name: src_harness
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstHarness to be added as a src-harness.

parameter.name: has_clock_wait
parameter.parameter_description: a #gboolean specifying if the #GstElement uses gst_clock_wait_id internally.

function.name: gst_harness_add_src_parse
function.description:
Similar to gst_harness_add_src, this allows you to specify a launch-line, which can be useful for both having more then one #GstElement acting as your src (Like a src producing raw buffers, and then an encoder, providing encoded data), but also by allowing you to set properties like "is-live" directly on the elements.
MT safe.

parameter.name: launchline
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar describing a gst-launch type line

parameter.name: has_clock_wait
parameter.parameter_description: a #gboolean specifying if the #GstElement uses gst_clock_wait_id internally.

function.name: gst_harness_buffers_in_queue
function.description:
The number of #GstBuffers currently in the #GstHarness sinkpad #GAsyncQueue
MT safe.
function.return: a #guint number of buffers in the queue

function.name: gst_harness_buffers_received
function.description:
The total number of #GstBuffers that has arrived on the #GstHarness sinkpad. This number includes buffers that have been dropped as well as buffers that have already been pulled out.
MT safe.
function.return: a #guint number of buffers received

function.name: gst_harness_crank_multiple_clock_waits
function.description:
Similar to gst_harness_crank_single_clock_wait(), this is the function to use if your harnessed element(s) are using more then one gst_clock_id_wait. Failing to do so can (and will) make it racy which #GstClockID you actually are releasing, where as this function will process all the waits at the same time, ensuring that one thread can't register another wait before both are released.
MT safe.

parameter.name: waits
parameter.parameter_description: a #guint describing the number of #GstClockIDs to crank

function.return: a @gboolean %TRUE if the "crank" was successful, %FALSE if not.

function.name: gst_harness_crank_single_clock_wait
function.description:
A "crank" consists of three steps: 1: Wait for a #GstClockID to be registered with the #GstTestClock. 2: Advance the #GstTestClock to the time the #GstClockID is waiting for. 3: Release the #GstClockID wait. Together, this provides an easy way to not have to think about the details around clocks and time, but still being able to write deterministic tests that are dependant on this. A "crank" can be though of as the notion of manually driving the clock forward to its next logical step.
MT safe.
function.return: a @gboolean %TRUE if the "crank" was successful, %FALSE if not.

function.name: gst_harness_create_buffer
function.description:
Allocates a buffer using a #GstBufferPool if present, or else using the configured #GstAllocator and #GstAllocationParams
MT safe.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: a #gsize specifying the size of the buffer

function.return: a #GstBuffer of size @size

function.name: gst_harness_dump_to_file
function.description:
Allows you to dump the #GstBuffers the #GstHarness sinkpad #GAsyncQueue to a file.
MT safe.

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with a the name of a file

function.name: gst_harness_events_in_queue
function.description:
The number of #GstEvents currently in the #GstHarness sinkpad #GAsyncQueue
MT safe.
function.return: a #guint number of events in the queue

function.name: gst_harness_events_received
function.description:
The total number of #GstEvents that has arrived on the #GstHarness sinkpad This number includes events handled by the harness as well as events that have already been pulled out.
MT safe.
function.return: a #guint number of events received

function.name: gst_harness_find_element
function.description:
Most useful in conjunction with gst_harness_new_parse, this will scan the #GstElements inside the #GstHarness, and check if any of them matches @element_name. Typical usecase being that you need to access one of the harnessed elements for properties and/or signals.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstElement or %NULL if not found

function.name: gst_harness_get
function.description:
A convenience function to allows you to call g_object_get on a #GstElement that are residing inside the #GstHarness, by using normal g_object_get syntax.
MT safe.

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the first property name

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the first property, followed optionally by more name/return location pairs, followed by %NULL

function.name: gst_harness_get_allocator
function.description:
Gets the @allocator and its @params that has been decided to use after an allocation query.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_harness_get_last_pushed_timestamp
function.description:
Get the timestamp of the last #GstBuffer pushed on the #GstHarness srcpad, typically with gst_harness_push or gst_harness_push_from_src.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstClockTime with the timestamp or %GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE if no #GstBuffer has been pushed on the #GstHarness srcpad

function.name: gst_harness_get_testclock
function.description:
Get the #GstTestClock. Useful if specific operations on the testclock is needed.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstTestClock, or %NULL if the testclock is not present.

function.name: gst_harness_new
function.description:
Creates a new harness. Works like gst_harness_new_with_padnames(), except it assumes the #GstElement sinkpad is named "sink" and srcpad is named "src"
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstHarness, or %NULL if the harness could not be created

function.name: gst_harness_new_empty
function.description:
Creates a new empty harness. Use gst_harness_add_element_full() to add an #GstElement to it.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstHarness, or %NULL if the harness could not be created

function.name: gst_harness_new_full
function.description:
Creates a new harness.
MT safe.

parameter.name: element
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstElement to attach the harness to (transfer none)

parameter.name: hsrc
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstStaticPadTemplate describing the harness srcpad. %NULL will not create a harness srcpad.

parameter.name: element_sinkpad_name
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the name of the element sinkpad that is then linked to the harness srcpad. Can be a static or request or a sometimes pad that has been added. %NULL will not get/request a sinkpad from the element. (Like if the element is a src.)

parameter.name: hsink
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstStaticPadTemplate describing the harness sinkpad. %NULL will not create a harness sinkpad.

parameter.name: element_srcpad_name

function.return: a #GstHarness, or %NULL if the harness could not be created

function.name: gst_harness_new_parse
function.description:
Creates a new harness, parsing the @launchline and putting that in a #GstBin, and then attches the harness to the bin.
MT safe.

parameter.name: launchline
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar describing a gst-launch type line

function.return: a #GstHarness, or %NULL if the harness could not be created

function.name: gst_harness_new_with_element
function.description:
Creates a new harness. Works in the same way as gst_harness_new_full(), only that generic padtemplates are used for the harness src and sinkpads, which will be sufficient in most usecases.
MT safe.

parameter.name: element
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstElement to attach the harness to (transfer none)

parameter.name: element_sinkpad_name
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the name of the element sinkpad that is then linked to the harness srcpad. %NULL does not attach a sinkpad

parameter.name: element_srcpad_name
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the name of the element srcpad that is then linked to the harness sinkpad. %NULL does not attach a srcpad

function.return: a #GstHarness, or %NULL if the harness could not be created

function.name: gst_harness_new_with_padnames
function.description:
Creates a new harness. Works like gst_harness_new_with_element(), except you specify the factoryname of the #GstElement
MT safe.

parameter.name: element_sinkpad_name
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the name of the element sinkpad that is then linked to the harness srcpad. %NULL does not attach a sinkpad

parameter.name: element_srcpad_name
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the name of the element srcpad that is then linked to the harness sinkpad. %NULL does not attach a srcpad

function.return: a #GstHarness, or %NULL if the harness could not be created

function.name: gst_harness_new_with_templates
function.description:
Creates a new harness, like gst_harness_new_full(), except it assumes the #GstElement sinkpad is named "sink" and srcpad is named "src"
MT safe.

parameter.name: hsrc
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstStaticPadTemplate describing the harness srcpad. %NULL will not create a harness srcpad.

parameter.name: hsink
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstStaticPadTemplate describing the harness sinkpad. %NULL will not create a harness sinkpad.

function.return: a #GstHarness, or %NULL if the harness could not be created

function.name: gst_harness_play
function.description:
This will set the harnessed #GstElement to %GST_STATE_PLAYING. #GstElements without a sink-#GstPad and with the %GST_ELEMENT_FLAG_SOURCE flag set is concidered a src #GstElement Non-src #GstElements (like sinks and filters) are automatically set to playing by the #GstHarness, but src #GstElements are not to avoid them starting to produce buffers. Hence, for src #GstElement you must call gst_harness_play() explicitly.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_harness_pull
function.description:
Pulls a #GstBuffer from the #GAsyncQueue on the #GstHarness sinkpad. The pull will timeout in 60 seconds. This is the standard way of getting a buffer from a harnessed #GstElement.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstBuffer or %NULL if timed out.

function.name: gst_harness_pull_event
function.description:
Pulls an #GstEvent from the #GAsyncQueue on the #GstHarness sinkpad. Timeouts after 60 seconds similar to gst_harness_pull.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstEvent or %NULL if timed out.

function.name: gst_harness_pull_upstream_event
function.description:
Pulls an #GstEvent from the #GAsyncQueue on the #GstHarness srcpad. Timeouts after 60 seconds similar to gst_harness_pull.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstEvent or %NULL if timed out.

function.name: gst_harness_push
function.description:
Pushes a #GstBuffer on the #GstHarness srcpad. The standard way of interacting with an harnessed element.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstFlowReturn with the result from the push

function.name: gst_harness_push_and_pull
function.description:
Basically a gst_harness_push and a gst_harness_pull in one line. Reflects the fact that you often want to do exactly this in your test: Push one buffer in, and inspect the outcome.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstBuffer or %NULL if timed out.

function.name: gst_harness_push_event
function.description:
Pushes an #GstEvent on the #GstHarness srcpad.
MT safe.
function.return: a #gboolean with the result from the push

function.name: gst_harness_push_from_src
function.description:
Transfer data from the src-#GstHarness to the main-#GstHarness. It consists of 4 steps: 1: Make sure the src is started. (see: gst_harness_play) 2: Crank the clock (see: gst_harness_crank_single_clock_wait) 3: Pull a #GstBuffer from the src-#GstHarness (see: gst_harness_pull) 4: Push the same #GstBuffer into the main-#GstHarness (see: gst_harness_push)
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstFlowReturn with the result of the push

function.name: gst_harness_push_to_sink
function.description:
Transfer one #GstBuffer from the main-#GstHarness to the sink-#GstHarness. See gst_harness_push_from_src for details.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstFlowReturn with the result of the push

function.name: gst_harness_push_upstream_event
function.description:
Pushes an #GstEvent on the #GstHarness sinkpad.
MT safe.
function.return: a #gboolean with the result from the push

function.name: gst_harness_query_latency
function.description:
Get the min latency reported by any harnessed #GstElement.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstClockTime with min latency

function.name: gst_harness_set
function.description:
A convenience function to allows you to call g_object_set on a #GstElement that are residing inside the #GstHarness, by using normal g_object_set syntax.
MT safe.

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: a #gchar with the first property name

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: value for the first property, followed optionally by more name/value pairs, followed by %NULL

function.name: gst_harness_set_blocking_push_mode
function.description:
Setting this will make the harness block in the chain-function, and then release when gst_harness_pull() or gst_harness_try_pull() is called. Can be useful when wanting to control a src-element that is not implementing gst_clock_id_wait() so it can't be controlled by the #GstTestClock, since it otherwise would produce buffers as fast as possible.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_harness_set_caps
function.description:
Sets the @GstHarness srcpad and sinkpad caps.
MT safe.

parameter.name: in
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstCaps to set on the harness srcpad

parameter.name: out
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstCaps to set on the harness sinkpad

function.name: gst_harness_set_caps_str
function.description:
Sets the @GstHarness srcpad and sinkpad caps using strings.
MT safe.

parameter.name: in
parameter.parameter_description: a @gchar describing a #GstCaps to set on the harness srcpad

parameter.name: out
parameter.parameter_description: a @gchar describing a #GstCaps to set on the harness sinkpad

function.name: gst_harness_set_drop_buffers
function.description:
When set to %TRUE, instead of placing the buffers arriving from the harnessed #GstElement inside the sinkpads #GAsyncQueue, they are instead unreffed.
MT safe.

parameter.name: drop_buffers
parameter.parameter_description: a #gboolean specifying to drop outgoing buffers or not

function.name: gst_harness_set_forwarding
function.description:
As a convenience, a src-harness will forward %GST_EVENT_STREAM_START, %GST_EVENT_CAPS and %GST_EVENT_SEGMENT to the main-harness if forwarding is enabled, and forward any sticky-events from the main-harness to the sink-harness. It will also forward the %GST_QUERY_ALLOCATION.
If forwarding is disabled, the user will have to either manually push these events from the src-harness using gst_harness_src_push_event(), or create and push them manually. While this will allow full control and inspection of these events, for the most cases having forwarding enabled will be sufficient when writing a test where the src-harness' main function is providing data for the main-harness.
Forwarding is enabled by default.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_harness_set_propose_allocator
function.description:
Sets the @allocator and @params to propose when receiving an allocation query.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_harness_set_sink_caps
function.description:
Sets the @GstHarness sinkpad caps.
MT safe.

parameter.name: caps
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstCaps to set on the harness sinkpad

function.name: gst_harness_set_sink_caps_str
function.description:
Sets the @GstHarness sinkpad caps using a string.
MT safe.

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: a @gchar describing a #GstCaps to set on the harness sinkpad

function.name: gst_harness_set_src_caps
function.description:
Sets the @GstHarness srcpad caps. This must be done before any buffers can legally be pushed from the harness to the element.
MT safe.

parameter.name: caps
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstCaps to set on the harness srcpad

function.name: gst_harness_set_src_caps_str
function.description:
Sets the @GstHarness srcpad caps using a string. This must be done before any buffers can legally be pushed from the harness to the element.
MT safe.

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: a @gchar describing a #GstCaps to set on the harness srcpad

function.name: gst_harness_set_time
function.description:
Advance the #GstTestClock to a specific time.
MT safe.

parameter.name: time
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstClockTime to advance the clock to

function.return: a @gboolean %TRUE if the time could be set. %FALSE if not.

function.name: gst_harness_set_upstream_latency
function.description:
Sets the min latency reported by #GstHarness when receiving a latency-query
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstClockTime with min latency

function.name: gst_harness_sink_push_many
function.description:
Convenience that calls gst_harness_push_to_sink @pushes number of times. Will abort the pushing if any one push fails.
MT safe.

parameter.name: pushes
parameter.parameter_description: a #gint with the number of calls to gst_harness_push_to_sink

function.return: a #GstFlowReturn with the result of the push

function.name: gst_harness_src_crank_and_push_many
function.description:
Transfer data from the src-#GstHarness to the main-#GstHarness. Similar to gst_harness_push_from_src, this variant allows you to specify how many cranks and how many pushes to perform. This can be useful for both moving a lot of data at the same time, as well as cases when one crank does not equal one buffer to push and v.v.
MT safe.

parameter.name: cranks
parameter.parameter_description: a #gint with the number of calls to gst_harness_crank_single_clock_wait

parameter.name: pushes
parameter.parameter_description: a #gint with the number of calls to gst_harness_push

function.return: a #GstFlowReturn with the result of the push

function.name: gst_harness_src_push_event
function.description:
Similar to what gst_harness_src_push does with #GstBuffers, this transfers a #GstEvent from the src-#GstHarness to the main-#GstHarness. Note that some #GstEvents are being transferred automagically. Look at sink_forward_pad for details.
MT safe.
function.return: a #gboolean with the result of the push

function.name: gst_harness_stress_custom_start
function.description:
Start a custom stress-thread that will call your @callback for every iteration allowing you to do something nasty.
MT safe.

parameter.name: init
parameter.parameter_description: a #GFunc that is called initially and only once

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GFunc that is called as often as possible

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: a #gpointer with custom data to pass to the @callback function

parameter.name: sleep
parameter.parameter_description: a #gulong specifying how long to sleep in (microseconds) for each call to the @callback

function.return: a #GstHarnessThread

function.name: gst_harness_stress_property_start_full
function.description:
Call g_object_set with @name and @value in intervals of @sleep microseconds
MT safe.

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: a #GValue to set the property to

parameter.name: sleep
parameter.parameter_description: a #gulong specifying how long to sleep in (microseconds) for each g_object_set with @name and @value

function.return: a #GstHarnessThread

function.name: gst_harness_stress_push_buffer_start_full
function.description:
Push a #GstBuffer in intervals of @sleep microseconds.
MT safe.

parameter.name: sleep
parameter.parameter_description: a #gulong specifying how long to sleep in (microseconds) for each call to gst_pad_push

function.return: a #GstHarnessThread

function.name: gst_harness_stress_push_buffer_with_cb_start_full
function.description:
Push a #GstBuffer returned by @func in intervals of @sleep microseconds.
MT safe.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstHarnessPrepareBufferFunc function called before every iteration to prepare / create a #GstBuffer for pushing

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: a #gpointer with data to the #GstHarnessPrepareBufferFunc function

parameter.name: notify
parameter.parameter_description: a #GDestroyNotify that is called when thread is stopped

parameter.name: sleep
parameter.parameter_description: a #gulong specifying how long to sleep in (microseconds) for each call to gst_pad_push

function.return: a #GstHarnessThread

function.name: gst_harness_stress_push_event_start_full

parameter.name: sleep
parameter.parameter_description: a #gulong specifying how long to sleep in (microseconds) for each gst_event_push with @event

function.return: a #GstHarnessThread

function.name: gst_harness_stress_push_event_with_cb_start_full
function.description:
Push a #GstEvent returned by @func onto the harnessed #GstElement sinkpad in intervals of @sleep microseconds.
MT safe.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstHarnessPrepareEventFunc function called before every iteration to prepare / create a #GstEvent for pushing

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: a #gpointer with data to the #GstHarnessPrepareEventFunc function

parameter.name: notify
parameter.parameter_description: a #GDestroyNotify that is called when thread is stopped

parameter.name: sleep
parameter.parameter_description: a #gulong specifying how long to sleep in (microseconds) for each call to gst_pad_push

function.return: a #GstHarnessThread

function.name: gst_harness_stress_push_upstream_event_start_full

parameter.name: sleep
parameter.parameter_description: a #gulong specifying how long to sleep in (microseconds) for each gst_event_push with @event

function.return: a #GstHarnessThread

function.name: gst_harness_stress_push_upstream_event_with_cb_start_full
function.description:
Push a #GstEvent returned by @func onto the harnessed #GstElement srcpad in intervals of @sleep microseconds.
MT safe.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: a #GstHarnessPrepareEventFunc function called before every iteration to prepare / create a #GstEvent for pushing

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: a #gpointer with data to the #GstHarnessPrepareEventFunc function

parameter.name: notify
parameter.parameter_description: a #GDestroyNotify that is called when thread is stopped

parameter.name: sleep
parameter.parameter_description: a #gulong specifying how long to sleep in (microseconds) for each call to gst_pad_push

function.return: a #GstHarnessThread

function.name: gst_harness_stress_requestpad_start_full
function.description:
Call gst_element_request_pad in intervals of @sleep microseconds
MT safe.

parameter.name: sleep
parameter.parameter_description: a #gulong specifying how long to sleep in (microseconds) for each gst_element_request_pad

function.return: a #GstHarnessThread

function.name: gst_harness_stress_statechange_start_full
function.description:
Change the state of your harnessed #GstElement from NULL to PLAYING and back again, only pausing for @sleep microseconds every time.
MT safe.

parameter.name: sleep
parameter.parameter_description: a #gulong specifying how long to sleep in (microseconds) for each state-change

function.return: a #GstHarnessThread

function.name: gst_harness_stress_thread_stop
function.description:
Stop the running #GstHarnessThread
MT safe.

function.name: gst_harness_teardown
function.description:
Tears down a @GstHarness, freeing all resources allocated using it.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_harness_try_pull
function.description:
Pulls a #GstBuffer from the #GAsyncQueue on the #GstHarness sinkpad. Unlike gst_harness_pull this will not wait for any buffers if not any are present, and return %NULL straight away.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstBuffer or %NULL if no buffers are present in the #GAsyncQueue

function.name: gst_harness_try_pull_event
function.description:
Pulls an #GstEvent from the #GAsyncQueue on the #GstHarness sinkpad. See gst_harness_try_pull for details.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstEvent or %NULL if no buffers are present in the #GAsyncQueue

function.name: gst_harness_try_pull_upstream_event
function.description:
Pulls an #GstEvent from the #GAsyncQueue on the #GstHarness srcpad. See gst_harness_try_pull for details.
MT safe.
function.return: a #GstEvent or %NULL if no buffers are present in the #GAsyncQueue

function.name: gst_harness_upstream_events_in_queue
function.description:
The number of #GstEvents currently in the #GstHarness srcpad #GAsyncQueue
MT safe.
function.return: a #guint number of events in the queue

function.name: gst_harness_upstream_events_received
function.description:
The total number of #GstEvents that has arrived on the #GstHarness srcpad This number includes events handled by the harness as well as events that have already been pulled out.
MT safe.
function.return: a #guint number of events received

function.name: gst_harness_use_systemclock
function.description:
Sets the system #GstClock on the @GstHarness #GstElement
MT safe.

function.name: gst_harness_use_testclock
function.description:
Sets the #GstTestClock on the #GstHarness #GstElement
MT safe.

function.name: gst_harness_wait_for_clock_id_waits
function.description:
Waits for @timeout seconds until @waits number of #GstClockID waits is registered with the #GstTestClock. Useful for writing deterministic tests, where you want to make sure that an expected number of waits have been reached.
MT safe.

parameter.name: waits
parameter.parameter_description: a #guint describing the numbers of #GstClockID registered with the #GstTestClock

parameter.name: timeout
parameter.parameter_description: a #guint describing how many seconds to wait for @waits to be true

function.return: a @gboolean %TRUE if the waits have been registered, %FALSE if not. (Could be that it timed out waiting or that more waits then waits was found)

function.name: gst_index_add_association
function.description: Associate given format/value pairs with each other. Be sure to pass gint64 values to this functions varargs, you might want to use a gint64 cast to be sure.

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the index to add the entry to

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: the id of the index writer

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: other format/value pairs or 0 to end the list

function.return: a pointer to the newly added entry in the index.

function.name: gst_index_add_associationv
function.description: Associate given format/value pairs with each other.

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the index to add the entry to

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: the id of the index writer

function.return: a pointer to the newly added entry in the index.

function.name: gst_index_add_format
function.description:
Adds a format entry into the index. This function is used to map dynamic #GstFormat ids to their original format key.
Free-function: gst_index_entry_free

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the index to add the entry to

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: the id of the index writer

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the format to add to the index

function.return: a pointer to the newly added entry in the index.

function.name: gst_index_add_id
function.description: Add an id entry into the index.

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the index to add the entry to

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: the id of the index writer

parameter.name: description
parameter.parameter_description: the description of the index writer

function.return: a pointer to the newly added entry in the index.

function.name: gst_index_add_object
function.description:
Add the given object to the index with the given key.
This function is not yet implemented.

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the index to add the object to

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: the id of the index writer

parameter.name: object
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the object to add

function.return: a pointer to the newly added entry in the index.

function.name: gst_index_commit
function.description: Tell the index that the writer with the given id is done with this index and is not going to write any more entries to it.

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: the writer that commited the index

function.name: gst_index_entry_assoc_map
function.description: Gets alternative formats associated with the indexentry.

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the format of the value the find

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to store the value

function.return: %TRUE if there was a value associated with the given format.

function.name: gst_index_entry_copy
function.description:
Copies an entry and returns the result.
Free-function: gst_index_entry_free
function.return: a newly allocated #GstIndexEntry.

function.name: gst_index_entry_free
function.description: Free the memory used by the given entry.

function.name: gst_index_get_assoc_entry
function.description: Finds the given format/value in the index

parameter.name: id

function.return: the entry associated with the value or %NULL if the value was not found.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data passed to the compare function

function.return: the entry associated with the value or %NULL if the value was not found.

function.name: gst_index_get_certainty
function.description: Get the certainty of the given index.

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the index to get the certainty of

function.return: the certainty of the index.

function.name: gst_index_get_group
function.description: Get the id of the current group.

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the index to get the current group from

function.return: the id of the current group.

function.name: gst_index_get_writer_id
function.description:
Before entries can be added to the index, a writer should obtain a unique id. The methods to add new entries to the index require this id as an argument.
The application can implement a custom function to map the writer object to a string. That string will be used to register or look up an id in the index.
<note> The caller must not hold @writer's GST_OBJECT_LOCK(), as the default resolver may call functions that take the object lock as well, and the lock is not recursive. </note>

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the index to get a unique write id for

parameter.name: writer
parameter.parameter_description: the #GstObject to allocate an id for

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a gint to hold the id

function.return: %TRUE if the writer would be mapped to an id.

function.name: gst_index_new
function.description: Create a new dummy index object. Use gst_element_set_index() to assign that to an element or pipeline. This index is not storing anything, but will still emit e.g. the #GstIndex::entry-added signal.
function.return: a new index object

parameter.name: user_data

function.description: Lets the app register a custom filter function so that it can select what entries should be stored in the index.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: data passed to the filter function

function.name: gst_index_set_group
function.description: Set the current groupnumber to the given argument.

function.return: %TRUE if the operation succeeded, %FALSE if the group did not exist.

function.name: gst_index_set_resolver
function.description: Lets the app register a custom function to map index ids to writer descriptions.

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the index to register the resolver on

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: data passed to the resolver function

function.description: Lets the app register a custom function to map index ids to writer descriptions.

parameter.parameter_description: data passed to the resolver function

function.name: gst_info_strdup_printf
function.description:
Allocates, fills and returns a null terminated string from the printf style @format string and corresponding arguments.
See gst_info_vasprintf() for when this function is required.
Free with g_free().
function.return: a newly allocated null terminated string or %NULL on any error

function.name: gst_info_strdup_vprintf
function.description:
Allocates, fills and returns a null terminated string from the printf style @format string and @args.
See gst_info_vasprintf() for when this function is required.
Free with g_free().

parameter.name: args
parameter.parameter_description: the va_list of printf arguments for @format

function.return: a newly allocated null terminated string or %NULL on any error

function.name: gst_info_vasprintf
function.description:
Allocates and fills a string large enough (including the terminating null byte) to hold the specified printf style @format and @args.
This function deals with the GStreamer specific printf specifiers #GST_PTR_FORMAT and #GST_SEGMENT_FORMAT. If you do not have these specifiers in your @format string, you do not need to use this function and can use alternatives such as g_vasprintf().
Free @result with g_free().

parameter.name: args
parameter.parameter_description: the va_list of printf arguments for @format

function.return: the length of the string allocated into @result or -1 on any error

function.name: gst_init
function.description:
Initializes the GStreamer library, setting up internal path lists, registering built-in elements, and loading standard plugins.
Unless the plugin registry is disabled at compile time, the registry will be loaded. By default this will also check if the registry cache needs to be updated and rescan all plugins if needed. See gst_update_registry() for details and section <link linkend="gst-running">Running GStreamer Applications</link> for how to disable automatic registry updates.
<note><para> This function will terminate your program if it was unable to initialize GStreamer for some reason. If you want your program to fall back, use gst_init_check() instead. </para></note>
WARNING: This function does not work in the same way as corresponding functions in other glib-style libraries, such as gtk_init\(\). In particular, unknown command line options cause this function to abort program execution.

function.name: gst_init_check
function.description:
Initializes the GStreamer library, setting up internal path lists, registering built-in elements, and loading standard plugins.
This function will return %FALSE if GStreamer could not be initialized for some reason. If you want your program to fail fatally, use gst_init() instead.

parameter.name: err
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to a #GError to which a message will be posted on error

function.return: %TRUE if GStreamer could be initialized.

function.name: gst_init_get_option_group
function.description:
Returns a #GOptionGroup with GStreamer's argument specifications. The group is set up to use standard GOption callbacks, so when using this group in combination with GOption parsing methods, all argument parsing and initialization is automated.
This function is useful if you want to integrate GStreamer with other libraries that use GOption (see g_option_context_add_group() ).
If you use this function, you should make sure you initialise the GLib threading system as one of the very first things in your program (see the example at the beginning of this section).
function.return: a pointer to GStreamer's option group.

function.name: gst_install_plugins_async
function.description:
Requests plugin installation without blocking. Once the plugins have been installed or installation has failed, @func will be called with the result of the installation and your provided @user_data pointer.
This function requires a running GLib/Gtk main loop. If you are not running a GLib/Gtk main loop, make sure to regularly call g_main_context_iteration(NULL,FALSE).
The installer strings that make up @detail are typically obtained by calling gst_missing_plugin_message_get_installer_detail() on missing-plugin messages that have been caught on a pipeline's bus or created by the application via the provided API, such as gst_missing_element_message_new().
It is possible to request the installation of multiple missing plugins in one go (as might be required if there is a demuxer for a certain format installed but no suitable video decoder and no suitable audio decoder).

parameter.name: details
parameter.parameter_description: NULL-terminated array of installer string details (see below)

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call when the installer program returns

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the user data to pass to @func when called, or NULL

function.return: result code whether an external installer could be started

function.name: gst_install_plugins_context_free
function.description: Frees a #GstInstallPluginsContext.

function.name: gst_install_plugins_context_new
function.description: Creates a new #GstInstallPluginsContext.
function.return: a new #GstInstallPluginsContext. Free with gst_install_plugins_context_free() when no longer needed

function.name: gst_install_plugins_context_set_confirm_search
function.description:
This function is used to tell the external installer process whether it should ask for confirmation or not before searching for missing plugins.
If set, this option will be passed to the installer via a --interaction=[show-confirm-search|hide-confirm-search] command line option.

parameter.name: confirm_search
parameter.parameter_description: whether to ask for confirmation before searching for plugins

function.name: gst_install_plugins_context_set_desktop_id
function.description:
This function is used to pass the calling application's desktop file ID to the external installer process.
A desktop file ID is the basename of the desktop file, including the .desktop extension.
If set, the desktop file ID will be passed to the installer via a --desktop-id= command line option.

parameter.name: desktop_id
parameter.parameter_description: the desktop file ID of the calling application

function.name: gst_install_plugins_context_set_startup_notification_id
function.description:
Sets the startup notification ID for the launched process.
This is typically used to to pass the current X11 event timestamp to the external installer process.
Startup notification IDs are defined in the [FreeDesktop.Org Startup Notifications standard](http://standards.freedesktop.org/startup-notification-spec/startup-notification-latest.txt).
If set, the ID will be passed to the installer via a --startup-notification-id= command line option.
GTK+/GNOME applications should be able to create a startup notification ID like this: <programlisting> timestamp = gtk_get_current_event_time (); startup_id = g_strdup_printf ("_TIME%u", timestamp); ... </programlisting>

function.name: gst_install_plugins_context_set_xid
function.description:
This function is for X11-based applications (such as most Gtk/Qt applications on linux/unix) only. You can use it to tell the external installer the XID of your main application window. That way the installer can make its own window transient to your application window during the installation.
If set, the XID will be passed to the installer via a --transient-for=XID command line option.
Gtk+/Gnome application should be able to obtain the XID of the top-level window like this: <programlisting> ##include <gtk/gtk.h> ##ifdef GDK_WINDOWING_X11 ##include <gdk/gdkx.h> ##endif ... ##ifdef GDK_WINDOWING_X11 xid = GDK_WINDOW_XWINDOW (GTK_WIDGET (application_window)->window); ##endif ... </programlisting>

parameter.name: xid
parameter.parameter_description: the XWindow ID (XID) of the top-level application

function.name: gst_install_plugins_installation_in_progress
function.description: Checks whether plugin installation (initiated by this application only) is currently in progress.
function.return: TRUE if plugin installation is in progress, otherwise FALSE

function.name: gst_install_plugins_return_get_name
function.description: Convenience function to return the descriptive string associated with a status code. This function returns English strings and should not be used for user messages. It is here only to assist in debugging.
function.return: a descriptive string for the status code in @ret

function.name: gst_install_plugins_supported
function.description: Checks whether plugin installation is likely to be supported by the current environment. This currently only checks whether the helper script that is to be provided by the distribution or operating system vendor exists.
function.return: TRUE if plugin installation is likely to be supported.

function.name: gst_install_plugins_sync
function.description:
Requests plugin installation and block until the plugins have been installed or installation has failed.
This function should almost never be used, it only exists for cases where a non-GLib main loop is running and the user wants to run it in a separate thread and marshal the result back asynchronously into the main thread using the other non-GLib main loop. You should almost always use gst_install_plugins_async() instead of this function.

parameter.name: details
parameter.parameter_description: NULL-terminated array of installer string details

function.return: the result of the installation.

function.name: gst_interpolation_control_source_new
function.description: This returns a new, unbound #GstInterpolationControlSource.
function.return: a new, unbound #GstInterpolationControlSource.

function.name: gst_is_dmabuf_memory
function.description: Check if @mem is dmabuf memory.
function.return: %TRUE if @mem is dmabuf memory, otherwise %FALSE

function.name: gst_is_fd_memory
function.description: Check if @mem is memory backed by an fd
function.return: %TRUE when @mem has an fd that can be retrieved with gst_fd_memory_get_fd().

function.name: gst_is_initialized
function.description: Use this function to check if GStreamer has been initialized with gst_init() or gst_init_check().
function.return: %TRUE if initialization has been done, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gst_is_missing_plugin_message
function.description: Checks whether @msg is a missing plugins message.
function.return: %TRUE if @msg is a missing-plugins message, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: gst_is_video_overlay_prepare_window_handle_message
function.description: Convenience function to check if the given message is a "prepare-window-handle" message from a #GstVideoOverlay.
function.return: whether @msg is a "prepare-window-handle" message

function.name: gst_iterator_copy
function.description: Copy the iterator and its state.
function.return: a new copy of @it.

function.name: gst_iterator_filter
function.description:
Create a new iterator from an existing iterator. The new iterator will only return those elements that match the given compare function @func. The first parameter that is passed to @func is the #GValue of the current iterator element and the second parameter is @user_data. @func should return 0 for elements that should be included in the filtered iterator.
When this iterator is freed, @it will also be freed.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the compare function to select elements

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data passed to the compare function

function.return:
a new #GstIterator.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_iterator_find_custom
function.description:
Find the first element in @it that matches the compare function @func. @func should return 0 when the element is found. The first parameter to @func will be the current element of the iterator and the second parameter will be @user_data. The result will be stored in @elem if a result is found.
The iterator will not be freed.
This function will return %FALSE if an error happened to the iterator or if the element wasn't found.

parameter.name: elem
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to a #GValue where to store the result

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data passed to the compare function

function.return:
Returns %TRUE if the element was found, else %FALSE.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_iterator_fold
function.description:
Folds @func over the elements of @iter. That is to say, @func will be called as @func (object, @ret, @user_data) for each object in @it. The normal use of this procedure is to accumulate the results of operating on the objects in @ret.
This procedure can be used (and is used internally) to implement the gst_iterator_foreach() and gst_iterator_find_custom() operations.
The fold will proceed as long as @func returns %TRUE. When the iterator has no more arguments, %GST_ITERATOR_DONE will be returned. If @func returns %FALSE, the fold will stop, and %GST_ITERATOR_OK will be returned. Errors or resyncs will cause fold to return %GST_ITERATOR_ERROR or %GST_ITERATOR_RESYNC as appropriate.
The iterator will not be freed.

parameter.name: ret
parameter.parameter_description: the seed value passed to the fold function

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data passed to the fold function

function.return:
A #GstIteratorResult, as described above.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_iterator_foreach
function.description: Iterate over all element of @it and call the given function @func for each element.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each element.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data passed to the function

function.return:
the result call to gst_iterator_fold(). The iterator will not be freed.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_iterator_free
function.description:
Free the iterator.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_iterator_new
function.description:
Create a new iterator. This function is mainly used for objects implementing the next/resync/free function to iterate a data structure.
For each item retrieved, the @item function is called with the lock held. The @free function is called when the iterator is freed.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of the iterator structure

parameter.name: master_cookie
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to a guint32 that is changed when the items in the iterator changed.

parameter.name: item
parameter.parameter_description: function to call on each item retrieved

function.return:
the new #GstIterator.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_iterator_new_list
function.description:
Create a new iterator designed for iterating @list.
The list you iterate is usually part of a data structure @owner and is protected with @lock.
The iterator will use @lock to retrieve the next item of the list and it will then call the @item function before releasing @lock again.
When a concurrent update to the list is performed, usually by @owner while holding @lock, @master_cookie will be updated. The iterator implementation will notice the update of the cookie and will return %GST_ITERATOR_RESYNC to the user of the iterator in the next call to gst_iterator_next().

parameter.name: lock
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to a #GMutex protecting the list.

parameter.name: master_cookie
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to a guint32 that is incremented when the list is changed.

parameter.name: item
parameter.parameter_description: function to call on each item retrieved

function.return:
the new #GstIterator for @list.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_iterator_new_single
function.description: This #GstIterator is a convenient iterator for the common case where a #GstIterator needs to be returned but only a single object has to be considered. This happens often for the #GstPadIterIntLinkFunction.

parameter.name: object
parameter.parameter_description: object that this iterator should return

function.return: the new #GstIterator for @object.

function.name: gst_iterator_next
function.description:
Get the next item from the iterator in @elem.
Only when this function returns %GST_ITERATOR_OK, @elem will contain a valid value. @elem must have been initialized to the type of the iterator or initialized to zeroes with g_value_unset(). The caller is responsible for unsetting or resetting @elem with g_value_unset() or g_value_reset() after usage.
When this function returns %GST_ITERATOR_DONE, no more elements can be retrieved from @it.
A return value of %GST_ITERATOR_RESYNC indicates that the element list was concurrently updated. The user of @it should call gst_iterator_resync() to get the newly updated list.
A return value of %GST_ITERATOR_ERROR indicates an unrecoverable fatal error.
function.return:
The result of the iteration. Unset @elem after usage.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_iterator_push
function.description:
Pushes @other iterator onto @it. All calls performed on @it are forwarded to @other. If @other returns %GST_ITERATOR_DONE, it is popped again and calls are handled by @it again.
This function is mainly used by objects implementing the iterator next function to recurse into substructures.
When gst_iterator_resync() is called on @it, @other will automatically be popped.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_iterator_resync
function.description:
Resync the iterator. this function is mostly called after gst_iterator_next() returned %GST_ITERATOR_RESYNC.
When an iterator was pushed on @it, it will automatically be popped again with this function.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_lfo_control_source_new
function.description: This returns a new, unbound #GstLFOControlSource.
function.return: a new, unbound #GstLFOControlSource.

function.name: gst_memory_alignment
function.description: The default memory alignment in bytes - 1 an alignment of 7 would be the same as what malloc() guarantees.

function.name: gst_memory_copy
function.description: Return a copy of @size bytes from @mem starting from @offset. This copy is guaranteed to be writable. @size can be set to -1 to return a copy from @offset to the end of the memory region.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: size to copy, or -1 to copy to the end of the memory region

function.return: a new #GstMemory.

function.name: gst_memory_get_sizes
function.description: Get the current @size, @offset and @maxsize of @mem.
function.return: the current sizes of @mem

function.name: gst_memory_init
function.description: Initializes a newly allocated @mem with the given parameters. This function will call gst_mini_object_init() with the default memory parameters.

parameter.name: maxsize
parameter.parameter_description: the total size of the memory

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of valid data in the memory

function.name: gst_memory_is_span
function.description:
Check if @mem1 and mem2 share the memory with a common parent memory object and that the memory is contiguous.
If this is the case, the memory of @mem1 and @mem2 can be merged efficiently by performing gst_memory_share() on the parent object from the returned @offset.

parameter.name: offset
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a result offset

function.return: %TRUE if the memory is contiguous and of a common parent.

function.name: gst_memory_is_type
function.description: Check if @mem if allocated with an allocator for @mem_type.
function.return: %TRUE if @mem was allocated from an allocator for @mem_type.

function.name: gst_memory_make_mapped
function.description:
Create a #GstMemory object that is mapped with @flags. If @mem is mappable with @flags, this function returns the mapped @mem directly. Otherwise a mapped copy of @mem is returned.
This function takes ownership of old @mem and returns a reference to a new #GstMemory.
function.return: a #GstMemory object mapped with @flags or %NULL when a mapping is not possible.

function.name: gst_memory_map
function.description:
Fill @info with the pointer and sizes of the memory in @mem that can be accessed according to @flags.
This function can return %FALSE for various reasons: - the memory backed by @mem is not accessible with the given @flags. - the memory was already mapped with a different mapping.
@info and its contents remain valid for as long as @mem is valid and until gst_memory_unmap() is called.
For each gst_memory_map() call, a corresponding gst_memory_unmap() call should be done.
function.return: %TRUE if the map operation was successful.

function.name: gst_memory_new_wrapped
function.description:
Allocate a new memory block that wraps the given @data.
The prefix/padding must be filled with 0 if @flags contains #GST_MEMORY_FLAG_ZERO_PREFIXED and #GST_MEMORY_FLAG_ZERO_PADDED respectively.

parameter.name: notify
parameter.parameter_description: called with @user_data when the memory is freed

function.return: a new #GstMemory.

function.name: gst_memory_ref
function.description: Increase the refcount of this memory.
function.return: @memory (for convenience when doing assignments)

function.name: gst_memory_resize
function.description:
Resize the memory region. @mem should be writable and offset + size should be less than the maxsize of @mem.
#GST_MEMORY_FLAG_ZERO_PREFIXED and #GST_MEMORY_FLAG_ZERO_PADDED will be cleared when offset or padding is increased respectively.

function.name: gst_memory_share
function.description: Return a shared copy of @size bytes from @mem starting from @offset. No memory copy is performed and the memory region is simply shared. The result is guaranteed to be non-writable. @size can be set to -1 to return a shared copy from @offset to the end of the memory region.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: size to share, or -1 to share to the end of the memory region

function.return: a new #GstMemory.

function.name: gst_memory_unmap
function.description: Release the memory obtained with gst_memory_map()

function.name: gst_memory_unref
function.description: Decrease the refcount of an memory, freeing it if the refcount reaches 0.

function.name: gst_message_copy
function.description: Creates a copy of the message. Returns a copy of the message.
function.return:
a new copy of @msg.
MT safe

function.name: gst_message_get_seqnum
function.description:
Retrieve the sequence number of a message.
Messages have ever-incrementing sequence numbers, which may also be set explicitly via gst_message_set_seqnum(). Sequence numbers are typically used to indicate that a message corresponds to some other set of messages or events, for example a SEGMENT_DONE message corresponding to a SEEK event. It is considered good practice to make this correspondence when possible, though it is not required.
Note that events and messages share the same sequence number incrementor; two events or messages will never have the same sequence number unless that correspondence was made explicitly.
function.return:
The message's sequence number.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_get_stream_status_object
function.description: Extracts the object managing the streaming thread from @message.
function.return: a GValue containing the object that manages the streaming thread. This object is usually of type GstTask but other types can be added in the future. The object remains valid as long as @message is valid.

function.name: gst_message_get_structure
function.description: Access the structure of the message.
function.return:
The structure of the message. The structure is still owned by the message, which means that you should not free it and that the pointer becomes invalid when you free the message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_has_name
function.description: Checks if @message has the given @name. This function is usually used to check the name of a custom message.
function.return: %TRUE if @name matches the name of the message structure.

function.name: gst_message_is_writable
function.description: Tests if you can safely write into a message's structure or validly modify the seqnum and timestamp fields.

function.name: gst_message_make_writable
function.description: Checks if a message is writable. If not, a writable copy is made and returned.
function.return:
a message (possibly a duplicate) that is writable.
MT safe

function.name: gst_message_new_application
function.description: Create a new application-typed message. GStreamer will never create these messages; they are a gift from us to you. Enjoy.

parameter.name: structure
parameter.parameter_description: the structure for the message. The message will take ownership of the structure.

function.return:
The new application message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_async_done
function.description: The message is posted when elements completed an ASYNC state change. @running_time contains the time of the desired running_time when this elements goes to PLAYING. A value of #GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE for @running_time means that the element has no clock interaction and thus doesn't care about the running_time of the pipeline.
function.return:
The new async_done message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_async_start
function.description: This message is posted by elements when they start an ASYNC state change.
function.return:
The new async_start message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_buffering
function.description:
Create a new buffering message. This message can be posted by an element that needs to buffer data before it can continue processing. @percent should be a value between 0 and 100. A value of 100 means that the buffering completed.
When @percent is < 100 the application should PAUSE a PLAYING pipeline. When @percent is 100, the application can set the pipeline (back) to PLAYING. The application must be prepared to receive BUFFERING messages in the PREROLLING state and may only set the pipeline to PLAYING after receiving a message with @percent set to 100, which can happen after the pipeline completed prerolling.
MT safe.
function.return: The new buffering message.

function.name: gst_message_new_clock_lost
function.description:
Create a clock lost message. This message is posted whenever the clock is not valid anymore.
If this message is posted by the pipeline, the pipeline will select a new clock again when it goes to PLAYING. It might therefore be needed to set the pipeline to PAUSED and PLAYING again.
function.return:
The new clock lost message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_clock_provide
function.description:
Create a clock provide message. This message is posted whenever an element is ready to provide a clock or lost its ability to provide a clock (maybe because it paused or became EOS).
This message is mainly used internally to manage the clock selection.

parameter.name: ready
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the sender can provide a clock

function.return:
the new provide clock message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_custom
function.description: Create a new custom-typed message. This can be used for anything not handled by other message-specific functions to pass a message to the app. The structure field can be %NULL.

parameter.name: structure
parameter.parameter_description: the structure for the message. The message will take ownership of the structure.

function.return:
The new message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_device_added
function.description: Creates a new device-added message. The device-added message is produced by #GstDeviceProvider or a #GstDeviceMonitor. They announce the appearance of monitored devices.
function.return: a newly allocated #GstMessage

function.name: gst_message_new_device_removed
function.description: Creates a new device-removed message. The device-removed message is produced by #GstDeviceProvider or a #GstDeviceMonitor. They announce the disappearance of monitored devices.
function.return: a newly allocated #GstMessage

function.name: gst_message_new_duration_changed
function.description: Create a new duration changed message. This message is posted by elements that know the duration of a stream when the duration changes. This message is received by bins and is used to calculate the total duration of a pipeline. Elements may post a duration message with a duration of GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE to indicate that the duration has changed and the cached duration should be discarded. The new duration can then be retrieved via a query.
function.return:
The new duration-changed message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_element
function.description: Create a new element-specific message. This is meant as a generic way of allowing one-way communication from an element to an application, for example "the firewire cable was unplugged". The format of the message should be documented in the element's documentation. The structure field can be %NULL.

parameter.name: structure
parameter.parameter_description: The structure for the message. The message will take ownership of the structure.

function.return:
The new element message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_eos
function.description: Create a new eos message. This message is generated and posted in the sink elements of a GstBin. The bin will only forward the EOS message to the application if all sinks have posted an EOS message.
function.return:
The new eos message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_error
function.description: Create a new error message. The message will copy @error and @debug. This message is posted by element when a fatal event occurred. The pipeline will probably (partially) stop. The application receiving this message should stop the pipeline.
function.return:
the new error message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_have_context
function.description: This message is posted when an element has a new local #GstContext.
function.return:
The new have-context message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_info
function.return: the new info message.

function.name: gst_message_new_latency
function.description: This message can be posted by elements when their latency requirements have changed.
function.return:
The new latency message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_need_context
function.description: This message is posted when an element needs a specific #GstContext.

parameter.name: context_type
parameter.parameter_description: The context type that is needed

function.return:
The new need-context message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_new_clock
function.description: Create a new clock message. This message is posted whenever the pipeline selects a new clock for the pipeline.
function.return:
The new new clock message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_progress

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: free, user visible text describing the progress

function.return: The new qos message.

function.name: gst_message_new_qos

parameter.name: live
parameter.parameter_description: if the message was generated by a live element

parameter.name: running_time
parameter.parameter_description: the running time of the buffer that generated the message

parameter.name: stream_time
parameter.parameter_description: the stream time of the buffer that generated the message

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: the timestamps of the buffer that generated the message

parameter.name: duration
parameter.parameter_description: the duration of the buffer that generated the message

function.return:
The new qos message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_request_state
function.description: This message can be posted by elements when they want to have their state changed. A typical use case would be an audio server that wants to pause the pipeline because a higher priority stream is being played.
function.return:
the new request state message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_reset_time
function.description: This message is posted when the pipeline running-time should be reset to @running_time, like after a flushing seek.
function.return:
The new reset_time message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_segment_done
function.description: Create a new segment done message. This message is posted by elements that finish playback of a segment as a result of a segment seek. This message is received by the application after all elements that posted a segment_start have posted the segment_done.

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: The format of the position being done

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: The position of the segment being done

function.return:
the new segment done message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_segment_start
function.description: Create a new segment message. This message is posted by elements that start playback of a segment as a result of a segment seek. This message is not received by the application but is used for maintenance reasons in container elements.

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: The format of the position being played

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: The position of the segment being played

function.return:
the new segment start message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_state_changed
function.description: Create a state change message. This message is posted whenever an element changed its state.
function.return:
the new state change message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_state_dirty
function.description: Create a state dirty message. This message is posted whenever an element changed its state asynchronously and is used internally to update the states of container objects.
function.return:
the new state dirty message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_step_done

parameter.name: rate
parameter.parameter_description: the rate of the stepped amount

function.return:
the new step_done message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_step_start

parameter.name: active
parameter.parameter_description: if the step is active or queued

parameter.name: rate
parameter.parameter_description: the rate of the stepped amount

function.return:
The new step_start message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_stream_start
function.description: Create a new stream_start message. This message is generated and posted in the sink elements of a GstBin. The bin will only forward the STREAM_START message to the application if all sinks have posted an STREAM_START message.
function.return:
The new stream_start message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_stream_status
function.description: Create a new stream status message. This message is posted when a streaming thread is created/destroyed or when the state changed.
function.return:
the new stream status message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_structure_change
function.description:
Create a new structure change message. This message is posted when the structure of a pipeline is in the process of being changed, for example when pads are linked or unlinked.
@src should be the sinkpad that unlinked or linked.

parameter.name: busy
parameter.parameter_description: Whether the structure change is busy.

function.return:
the new structure change message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_tag
function.description: Create a new tag message. The message will take ownership of the tag list. The message is posted by elements that discovered a new taglist.

parameter.name: tag_list
parameter.parameter_description: the tag list for the message.

function.return:
the new tag message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_toc
function.description: Create a new TOC message. The message is posted by elements that discovered or updated a TOC.

parameter.name: updated
parameter.parameter_description: whether TOC was updated or not.

function.return:
a new TOC message.
MT safe.

function.name: gst_message_new_warning
function.description: Create a new warning message. The message will make copies of @error and @debug.
function.return:
The new warning message.
MT safe.

function.description:
Extract the running_time from the async_done message.

parameter.name: running_time
parameter.parameter_description: Result location for the running_time or %NULL

Extracts the buffering percent from the GstMessage. see also gst_message_new_buffering().

Extracts the lost clock from the GstMessage. The clock object returned remains valid until the message is freed.

Extracts the clock and ready flag from the GstMessage. The clock object returned remains valid until the message is freed.

parameter.name: ready
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to hold the ready flag, or %NULL

function.name: gst_message_parse_context_type
function.description: Parse a context type from an existing GST_MESSAGE_NEED_CONTEXT message.
function.return: a #gboolean indicating if the parsing succeeded.

function.name: gst_message_parse_device_added

Extract the context from the HAVE_CONTEXT message.

Extracts the new clock from the GstMessage. The clock object returned remains valid until the message is freed.

parameter.name: clock

function.name: gst_message_parse_progress
function.description: Parses the progress @type, @code and @text.

function.name: gst_message_parse_qos
function.description:
Extract the timestamps and live status from the QoS message.
The returned values give the running_time, stream_time, timestamp and duration of the dropped buffer. Values of GST_CLOCK_TIME_NONE mean unknown values.
MT safe.

parameter.name: live
parameter.parameter_description: if the message was generated by a live element

parameter.name: running_time
parameter.parameter_description: the running time of the buffer that generated the message

parameter.name: stream_time
parameter.parameter_description: the stream time of the buffer that generated the message

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: the timestamps of the buffer that generated the message

parameter.name: duration

function.name: gst_message_parse_qos_stats
function.description:
Extract the QoS stats representing the history of the current continuous pipeline playback period.
When @format is @GST_FORMAT_UNDEFINED both @dropped and @processed are invalid. Values of -1 for either @processed or @dropped mean unknown values.
MT safe.

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: Units of the 'processed' and 'dropped' fields. Video sinks and video filters will use GST_FORMAT_BUFFERS (frames). Audio sinks and audio filters will likely use GST_FORMAT_DEFAULT (samples).

parameter.name: processed
parameter.parameter_description: Total number of units correctly processed since the last state change to READY or a flushing operation.

parameter.name: dropped
parameter.parameter_description: Total number of units dropped since the last state change to READY or a flushing operation.

function.name: gst_message_parse_qos_values
function.description:
Extract the QoS values that have been calculated/analysed from the QoS data
MT safe.

parameter.name: jitter
parameter.parameter_description: The difference of the running-time against the deadline.

parameter.name: proportion
parameter.parameter_description: Long term prediction of the ideal rate relative to normal rate to get optimal quality.

parameter.name: quality
parameter.parameter_description: An element dependent integer value that specifies the current quality level of the element. The default maximum quality is 1000000.
